translated: The Monastic Code of the Elders
The Great Analysis🔽The chapter on training rules
The training rule on licking the hands

original: Tena samayena buddho bhagavā sāvatthiyaṁ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
analyzed: tena samayena buddhaḥ bhagavā sāvatthiyam viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme
translated: At one time when the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery,

original: Tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyā bhikkhū hatthanillehakaṁ bhuñjanti …pe….
analyzed: tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyāḥ bhikkhū hattha nillehakam bhuñjanti pe
translated: the monks from the group of six were licking their hands while eating. …

analyzed: na hattha nillehakam bhuñjissāmi iti sikkhā karaṇīyā ati
translated: “‘I will not lick my hands while eating,’ this is how you should train.”
One should not lick one’s hands while eating.

original: Yo anādariyaṁ paṭicca hatthanillehakaṁ bhuñjati, āpatti dukkaṭassa.🔽Anāpatti—
analyzed: yaḥ anādariyam paṭicca hattha nillehakam bhuñjati āpatti dukkaṭassa  anāpatti
translated: If a monk, out of disrespect, licks his hands while eating, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.

There is no offense if it is unintentional, if he is not thinking, if he is sick, if he licks only the back of the hand, if he licks the hand after wiping a bowl, if he licks the hand after wiping a drinking cup, if he licks the hand after wiping a water filter, if he licks the hand after wiping the mouth, if he licks the hand after wiping away sweat, if he is insane, if he is the first offender.
The second training rule is finished.
